entry.title: Healthcare integration - Patient as a business partner in SAP Cloud ERP Private
entry.content:
In this blog, I'll give a sneak preview on various integration possibilities between Hospital Information Systems and an ERP system. I'll go into details about an integration package which creates patient as a business partner in SAP Cloud ERP Private. In the healthcare context, integration of patient data is important with most of the business process inside a hospital revolves around the patient. Before I go into details of the integration package, let’s first understand a few key words and use case.

Key words

SAP Cloud ERP Private refers to SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition.

SAP BTP refers to SAP Business Technology Platform.

Integration Packages are a set of preconfigured integration artifacts for specific business process between various systems involved. 

Business Partner in SAP Cloud ERP Private is a central master data object that represents an organization, person, or group of people showing a business relationship.

FHIR refers to Fast Healthcare Interoperability Resources. FHIR® is the registered trademarks of Health Level Seven International.

Perspective

There are many use cases where hospital data is available in an EMR (Electronic Medical Record) system like treatment, staffs and care-givers, billing and claims and so on. This data needs to be exchanged with SAP Cloud ERP Private to do business processes.

We need data exchange to improve agility and clarity for effective decision-making and to adapt for business transformation correctly.

Patient as a business partner is just one of the integration use cases. The integration package which I talk about in this blog offers template and guidance to integrate more such data. Entities like departments, vendors, personnel (Doctors and Hospital staffs), insurance, and so on, are some examples of data needed for integration. Such data integration will help in realizing business processes for finance, supply chain, workforce management and so on.

SAP Health Data Services for FHIR supports all the FHIR resources and serves as a domain model for data integration between EMR and SAP Cloud ERP Private.

Use Case

Why we need to represent the patient as a business partner? Let’s consider billing as an example at the hospital, where a patient could be a self-payer or a co-payer. We need to do Account Receivable management in SAP Cloud ERP Private for payment tracking and collection.  

Hence, the patient needs to be kept as a business partner in SAP Cloud ERP Private.

Onboarding - SAP Health Data Services for FHIR

For integration to be established, you need to have a key BTP service which is SAP Health Data Services for FHIR. For details, refer to the following link:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_HEALTH_DATA_SERVICES_FOR_FHIR/f64d5f2b858042f791b64bdd4094df22/872ceb743a38498bb960b916de6cde5d.html

This onboarding steps are made simple using the BTP booster which automates all the onboarding steps for you, and you can refer to the following link:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_HEALTH_DATA_SERVICES_FOR_FHIR/4613ca2972b540168ab4e03bf72023d7/de0e3033cda5477691db3bd521bbb163.html

Another step is to configure the patient resource in SAP Health Data Services for FHIR by profiling the patient resource. Refer the following link:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_HEALTH_DATA_SERVICES_FOR_FHIR/88d3c4c1e7bd416cb4f23907e0a4641d/f754dd80490a41c996927fac6116feba.html

Setting up access control in cloud connector

We need this step to establish secure communication between SAP BTP and SAP Cloud ERP Private.

Use the following link to complete the setup of access control in the cloud connector.

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_HEALTH_DATA_SERVICES_FOR_FHIR/88d3c4c1e7bd416cb4f23907e0a4641d/de25990e3bfb40c29cdc2a6df49fd63e.html

Finding an Integration Package

  • Go to https://api.sap.com/ and select “Integration”.

 

  • Then in the following tabbed options select “Discover Integrations” and enter “SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition” in the “Find” to search.

 

  • Enter “SAP Health Data Services for FHIR” as a product to integrate. You'll get the integration package as shown after this.

 

  • Select the package to view its content. You'll see that it includes one Integration Flow “Replicate Patients from SAP Health Data Services for FHIR to SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition”.

Importing Integration Package

There are two ways in which an integration package can be imported and executed.

  • Using the configured workspace of the SAP Business Accelerator Hub. Steps are described here:

https://help.sap.com/docs/business-accelerator-hub/sap-business-accelerator-hub/consume-content?version=Cloud

  • Copying the integration content in the SAP Cloud Integration Suite (Recommended)

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_HEALTH_DATA_SERVICES_FOR_FHIR/88d3c4c1e7bd416cb4f23907e0a4641d/38a01529209a4dc999ded3b9dd05a552.html

  • Once imported into the Integration Suite, you can see the package in the “Design” tab.

Configurations

  • Setting up cloud connector in SAP BTP for secure communication with SAP Cloud ERP Private.

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_HEALTH_DATA_SERVICES_FOR_FHIR/88d3c4c1e7bd416cb4f23907e0a4641d/de25990e3bfb40c29cdc2a6df49fd63e.html

  • Maintain the message queue
    • Make sure you have the proper role collection assigned to your user in BTP. Refer the link: https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_HEALTH_DATA_SERVICES_FOR_FHIR/88d3c4c1e7bd416cb4f23907e0a4641d/799852ea657e400fa07700e976285b14.html
    • Navigate to the BTP dashboard to locate an Event Mesh service instance bound to SAP Health Data Services for FHIR instance.
    • Go to the Event Mesh application.

    • Click on the proper “Message Client” in the Event Mesh dashboard. Client here refers to the Event Mesh service instance which you've created along with SAP Health Data Services for FHIR provisioning.

    • Click on the tab “Queues” and then “Create Queue”.

    • In the subsequent pop-up window, offer your own queue name and click on create. Don't enter values for any other fields. Next for the created queue, click on the “Actions” column as highlighted in blue and select “Queue Subscriptions”.

    • In the subsequent pop-up window, offer the topic as “coredata/Patient”, click on Add and then close the window.

    • This completes the Event Mesh configuration.
  • Security Material in Integration Suite.
    • Go to the Integration Suite subscription application in your sub-account.

  • Click on “Monitor”, next “Integrations and APIs” and then “Security Materials”.

  • Maintain “Security Materials” for the three application and services involved in the integration like following. All the needed information can be retrieved from the service key of the respective services. For each Security Material after filling in the needed inputs, click on Deploy. Ensure that the grant type is as shown. Use the following link to get a detailed description about each field value and configuration.

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_HEALTH_DATA_SERVICES_FOR_FHIR/88d3c4c1e7bd416cb4f23907e0a4641d/cd5f25e58497425d9f500f0abbd39363.html#procedure

  • Security Material for Event Mesh.

  • Security Material for SAP Health Data Services for FHIR.

  • Security Material for SAP Cloud ERP Private.

  • This completes the security credential configuration in SAP Integration Suite.

 

  • Configure integration package artifact.
    • Navigate to the iFlow inside the copied integration package.

  • Click on the “Artifacts” tab, select the iFlow and click on Configure.

  • In the next pop-up window, enter the following details for the “Sender”, “Receiver” and “More” tab.
  • Use the following link to get a detailed description about each field value and configuration.

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_HEALTH_DATA_SERVICES_FOR_FHIR/88d3c4c1e7bd416cb4f23907e0a4641d/c1e3e07667f6463f9b68f0bd446e1c02.html

  • Enter the following details in the “Receiver” tab.

  • Enter the following details in the “More” tab.

  • Click “Deploy All” to deploy the configuration.

Monitoring

After the above configuration deployment, integration flow status changes to “Started” and can be monitored. Use the following link to monitor the integration.

https://help.sap.com/docs/integration-suite/sap-integration-suite/monitor-integrations

When patient is created in SAP Health Data Services for FHIR, based on the preceding steps, the integration flow will automatically create the corresponding business partner in SAP Cloud ERP Private.

Conclusion

With this, I'll like to summarize the blog.

Blog offers you a step-by-step guide to realize integration for the patient data as a business partner in SAP Cloud ERP Private. Share your experience about the integration package, application, and services used during integration. Are you familiar with the FHIR standard and the resources? If yes, then how do you use within your hospital landscape and for interoperability between systems.

Do let us know through the comments. I'll love to hear your reactions and feedback through comments.

entry.title: Re: Issue with Budget Display in "Monitor Project" App –...
entry.content: I’ve run into the same budget display issue in the Monitor Project app on SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. In many cases, it’s caused by missing or incomplete configuration in project control settings or budgeting not being released properly. Make sure the project has an active financial plan and that the relevant WBS elements are assigned correctly. Also check whether the budget profile is activated and if the authorization roles allow budget viewing. A data refresh or cache clear sometimes helps as well. If everything looks right, submitting an SAP support ticket usually gets the issue resolved quickly.

entry.title: Streamlining Expat Air Ticket Allowances: How SAP Ticket Benefit Solution Meets MENA Workforce Needs
entry.content:
In the MENA region, expatriate employees are often entitled to receive air tickets for themselves and their dependents to travel back to their home countries. For HR and payroll teams, managing these entitlements accurately while staying compliant with local regulations and company policy can be complex. SAP Ticket Benefit solution offers a streamlined and flexible approach to address this challenge.

Overview of SAP Ticket Benefit Solution

The Ticket Benefit solution enables companies to manage ticket entitlements for expat employees and their dependents, whether provided as a monetary allowance or an actual ticket. It supports:

  • Flexible setup aligned with company policy
  • Annual, semi-annual, or custom frequencies
  • Configurable rules for dependents, travel routes, and ticket classes

High-Level Process Steps

Key Features

The solution is built on four core components:

  • Entitlement Recording - Infotype 3408
    The process begins by recording each employee’s entitlement details, such as: 
    • Accrual vs. in-full ticket
    • Frequency of ticket issuance
    • Number of tickets per cycle
    • Travel route and ticket class
    • Number of dependents covered

           These configurations allow organizations to accurately reflect their policies within the system.

  • Calculation - Payroll Function TBCAL
    During payroll runs, the function calculates the ticket balance for each employee and their dependents based on the Infotype records and the Ticket Benefit customizing settings. 

           This ensures entitlement values are updated and reflected in payroll results.

  • Ticket Compensation:
    • Issuing Ticket - Infotype 3409
      For companies that provide actual travel tickets instead of cash allowances, admins can record each ticket issuance directly in Infotype 3409 to keep the system aligned with the tickets provided.
    • Ticket Auto Encashment – Workbench
      The new Ticket Benefit Workbench further streamlines ticket allowance processing by identifying employees and dependents who have reached the end of their ticket cycle. It enables bulk creation of compensation records, reducing manual effort while improving process consistency and transparency. For implementation details, please refer to SAP Note 3680164.
  • Correction - Infotype 3410
    When adjustments are required, Infotype 3410 allows admins to specify who the correction applies to and add or deduct the appropriate number of tickets. This ensures ticket balances remain accurate and up to date.

Conclusion

The SAP Ticket Benefit solution is more than a compliance enabler. By leveraging this solution, organizations can:

  • Improve operational efficiency through automation and bulk processing
  • Maintain accurate entitlement records
  • Enhance employee satisfaction

For detailed documentation and configuration guidance, refer to the SAP Help Portal.

entry.title: Considerations when implementing IAS for SuccessFactors Onboarding
entry.content:
In H2 2026 the username and password authentication process for onboarding will be deprecated and they will need to use IAS to log in.  In this article we will discuss various options to consider when implementing IAS for onboarding.  We will assume that IAS is already enabled for Employee Central.

Implementing IAS is quite simple for an onboarding perspective, a switch is enabled in provisioning and emails need to be adjusted.  All the logic in IAS should be built by an IAS consultant.

Emails

When IAS is enabled for onboarding the ‘username/password’ is sent from IAS rather than from SuccessFactors.  I prefer to still send the ‘External Welcome email’ from SuccessFactors Onboarding.  The welcome email explains that they will get a second email with the login credentials.  I prefer to send two emails as we can customize this email to a greater extent than the IAS email.  In the welcome email you will need to remove the password reset and username, and this will need to be removed for the rehire email as well.  The login link in the other emails will work with IAS.

To get two emails to be sent at the same time will require the real time synch in IAS.

The first email comes from SuccessFactors Onboarding.  This is the external email welcome template. 

The second email comes at the same time from IAS and will allow them to set their password to log in.

To log on they click on the link, and they set their password.

Once they have reset their password they should be redirect to the login page; to do this you will need to set up the redirect in IAS.

Once they have submitted their username and password you can choose to add a new layer of authentication.  Once way is to send a code to their email address.  You can also send this by SMS but this will require a third party provider.

Once they submit the code they will be able to log in.

Once they log in, they can proceed with onboarding as normal.

On their hire date the individual will not get a new IAS account but will be moved to an employee group and they will be able to log in with same IAS account. 

Rehires

When an employee is terminated from Employee Central then their details are typically deleted from IAS, they can be made inactivated, but it is advised that they are deleted.  ips.delete.existedbefore.entities=true

When onboarding starts the onboardee receives an email as above.  When the rehire, check has been completed it follows the same process as without IAS, they get an new IAS email to go in that is linked to their inactive Employee Central Account.  As the old IAS account was deleted this is new IAS account but liked to the inactive user record.  Once they log in their can proceed with onboarding as normal.

When deploying IAS, it is imperative that the rehire process is fully tested.

Implementing IAS whilst live with Onboarding.

Some onboardees  will be using the old username and password method.  As you approach the deployment, we suggest the following.

  • About 2-3 weeks before go live update the welcome email so users know you are changing the authentication process, and they will get a new email to log in. 
  • Add this to a custom homepage tile, this is just there to prevent any concerns over phishing.
  • On go live day pause all initiation of onboarding
  • Update onboarding IAS email with text applicable to all onboardee who are currently in the process, explaining what they need to do.
  • Synch onboarding with IAS, once this is completed update onboarding IAS email with standard text
  • Restart onboarding initiation

entry.title: Re: Inclusion of field Requisitioner in Production Operat...
entry.content:
Hello @KeLaw 

Thank you for your question.

Below are some insightful links to support you:

Implementing a Business Add-in (BAdI): Check a Purchase Requisition, App Extensibility: My Purchase Requisitions, KBA 2955651

The simple answer to your question is NO, not in a supported way. Let me explain.

In summary, the public cloud due to its modular approach does not support adding the Requisitioner (AFNAM) field to the External Processing tab of an operation’s production-order because is a GUI application. Also, you cannot extend the GUI screen with key-user tools.

The choice of making AFNAM mandatory in your system will therefore block purchase requisitions that your system created automatically from external-processing operation because users have no place to maintain that field beforehand.

Instead of changing the PP operations UI, my suggestion is for you to use BAdI MM_PUR_S4_MODIFY_ITEM in the Custom Logic app to enable you derive and populate AFNAM automatically for your PR items which originate from production orders and then keep your existing check in MM_PUR_S4_PR_CHECK. This will ensure every purchase requisition has a valid requisitioner and you will also be sticking with the clean-core approach.

You may consider building a logic. below is a quick guide.

In your Custom Logic App, create a new enhancement implementation

Select as described in the screen (Business Context: Procurement: Purchase Requisition Item, BAdI: MM_PUR_S4_PR_MODIFY_ITEM). You can add logic that detects PR item,

derive a suitable requisitioner such as MRP Controller, set PurchaseRequisitionItem-Requistioner accordingly when it is initial.

You can keep your existing logic but only raise an error if AFNAM is still not initial after the system has run the modify BAdI.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: SAP CPI Best Practices for Designing High-Performance iFlows
entry.content:
Hello SAP Community!

  This is officially my first-ever blog, and I’m super excited (and slightly nervous) to share my learning with all of you. If you find this useful, please like, comment, or drop any suggestions that can help me improve. I truly appreciate your feedback!

Now, let’s get into the fun part:

“ SAP CPI Best Practices for Designing High-Performance iFlows.”

If you've ever created an iFlow that started simple but ended up looking like a bowl of spaghetti, trust me, I have been there too. CPI works best when we treat it gently, keep things clean, and avoid lifting heavy weights unnecessarily.

So here’s a friendly, simple, real-world explanation of how you can build faster, smarter, happier iFlows this year.

1. Keep Your iFlow Simple

Complex iFlow = Slow Performance

  Avoid unnecessary branches, loops, or overly stuffed mappings.

Visual Example:

BAD DESIGN (Spaghetti iFlow)

┌───[Start]

│

├───If

│     └──If

│         └──If

│             └──Groovy Script (200 lines)

│                 └──Mapping

│                     └──Another Mapping

│

└───[End]

GOOD DESIGN (Clean iFlow)

┌───[Start]

│

├───Router → Mapping → Script (If needed)

│

└───[End]

Real Example:

 A client had 10 content modifiers. After cleaning up unused ones and merging logic, the iFlow went from 24 seconds → 4 seconds.

2. Use Parallel Processing When Possible

If your work doesn’t depend on sequence, divide it!

Mini Diagram

               ┌── Branch A

[Input] → Fork ─┤

                └── Branch B

It’s like carrying groceries: why carry one tomato at a time when you have two hands?

Real Example:

Processing 500 employee records in parallel batches reduced execution time by 70%.

3. Reduce Message Size — CPI Is Not a Weightlifter

Large payloads slow down your CPI tenant.

 Don’t send the entire data package when you only need a few fields.

Funny Analogy:

  Like ordering a truck to deliver a packet of noodles.

 Your neighbors will judge you. CPI will too.

Real Example:

  A 12MB XML file was reduced to 3MB after removing unused segments, resulting in a significantly faster iFlow.

4. Use Groovy Scripts Wisely

Groovy is powerful… but don’t use it for everything.

 If a graphical mapping works, use it.

Groovy Logic Flow

Good Use Cases:

✔️Dynamic Header Setting

✔️Custom Transformations

✔️String Manipulation

Avoid:

✖️400-line mega scripts

✖️Full-blown mappings that CPI mapping can handle

Real Example:

  A huge mapping Groovy script was replaced with a graphical map → 60% performance boost.

5. Cache Reusable Data

If your iFlow needs the same lookup value 100 times, don’t call the API 100 times.

Simple Diagram

Without Cache

iFlow → API → API → API → API → ...

With Cache

iFlow → API (Once) → Store → Reuse → Reuse

Real Example:

  A currency service was called for each line item.

 After caching, API calls dropped by 99%, and the customer stopped calling me about performance issues.

6. Use the Right Adapter

Choose adapters based on your scenario needs.

Funny Analogy:

 Using a truck to deliver a biscuit technically works…

 But why… just why?

Real Example:

 Switching from SOAP to HTTPS adapter reduced processing time by 1.5 seconds per call.

7. Monitor Everything

CPI gives hints when something is wrong — in Message Monitoring, Logs, or Cloud ALM.

Funny Line:

 CPI is like a baby.

 It doesn’t stay quiet when something is wrong…

 It screams (in the logs).

Simple Monitoring Flow

Message Monitor → Check Logs → Identify Pattern → Fix iFlow → Re-test

Real Example:

Frequent Java heap space errors in logs revealed that large payloads were filling memory, and splitting messages fixed the issue immediately.

Final Thoughts

Designing high-performance iFlows in 2025 is all about being smart, simple, and intentional:

✔️Keep your iFlows clean

 ✔️ Reduce unnecessary steps

 ✔️ Avoid heavy payloads

 ✔️ Use scripts wisely

 ✔️ Monitor often

 ✔️ And don’t make CPI do gym workouts, it didn’t sign up for 

Thank you for reading my first-ever SAP Community blog!

 I’m really excited to keep learning and sharing here.

If you enjoyed it or have suggestions, please like, drop a comment, or share your advice.

 Your feedback will help me grow!

Thank you

Dinesh

entry.title: Re: Cannot change Home Page for SAP Build Work Zone advan...
entry.content:
If anyone else stumbles in here, for answer to why you can't edit the start page as admin, after completing the booster, I fixed this problem by renaming the display name of the group the "Workzone Admin" in SCIM under "Users & Authorizations" --> "Groups", to "Workzone_Admin".

The reason for this mismatch, is that the configuration (after completing the booster), states that the group display name must be "Workzone_Admin" - with the underscore in between the words, while the configuration guide tells you to name the group "Workzone Admin" with a space between the words.

entry.title: CORS Policy in SAC with live connection to BW
entry.content:
Hello!

We have been running SAC dashboards from our CRM system via an URL that is inserted in the CRM system.

Last week we had a security update on our network and now this is not working anymore. No changes have been made in BW or SAC!

We have a live BW connection with SAML to our SAC system and we have no problems running stories directly in SAC, it is when we call the stories from our CRM system we get the problem.

We get to SAC but when SAC calls BW we get the following error:

Access to XMLHttpRequest at 'https://lspappbw01.itpap.local:44300/sap/bw/ina/GetServerInfo?sap-client=010' from origin 'https://papyrus-1.eu10.hcs.cloud.sap' has been blocked by CORS policy: Permission was denied for this request to access the `unknown` address space.

Running the same URL directly in edge works fine and also in SAC.

Can you advice what to do?

 

/Maria

entry.title: Your key to next-level liquidity: Working Capital Management with SAP Taulia
entry.content:
Liquidity is crucial in today’s economic climate. While interest rates are rising and refinancing becomes ever more challenging for companies all sizes, a lack of liquidity can heavily disrupt your entire supply chain. So, it’s time to start thinking about your working capital strategy and SAP Taulia is here to help.

Being one of the key components in SAP S/4HANA Cloud’s treasury portfolio, SAP Taulia helps you to bring your working capital strategy to life. The cashflow orchestration platform is tightly integrated into SAP ERP and SAP Business Network, has access to many funders, delivers AI and analytics capabilities, and supports your sustainability journey as well.

 Curious? Let’s dive into more detail, SAP Taulia consists of two scope items that can be activated independently in your SAP ERP: 7DX (Receivables Financing with SAP Taulia) and 7MG (Payables Financing with SAP Taulia).

Scope item 7DX unlocks receivables financing capabilities in your ERP system. Shortly said, this enables you to unlock cash trapped in your invoices remarkably improving your cash flow.

Scope item 7MG covers the Payables side of your business, offering Virtual Cards, Dynamic Discounting and Supply Chain Finance. Dynamic Discounting basically means that you get a discount from suppliers in exchange for early payments. Supply Chain Finance, works similar, but instead a funder makes the early payment and you repay them later.  Virtual Cards, support you in automating and making your transactions safer and easier.

As of release S/4HANA Public Cloud 2508 7MG: Payables Financing with Taulia is the successor of 4AV: Supplier Finance in S/4HANA. Customers who want to set up Supplier Financing will now need to activate scope item 7MG.

This is of course only the tip of the iceberg. If you want to learn more about SAP Taulia, its value add for your business, customer examples, demos and more, I can sincerely recommend to take a look at the below resources:

  • Free learning journey, for a comprehensive overview
  • Solution overview, for a high level overview of SAP Taulia
  • Technical documentation, for an overview of everything that is available
  • Product Tours, for a sneak peek how the products look in the system
  • Follow SAP Taulia on Linkedin to not miss any new updates

entry.title: Re: S/4HANA Public Cloud - API Availability for BP Extens...
entry.content:
Dear @byd,

Question 1.

Answer: Yes

Standard API:

  • API name (business): Business Partner (A2X) OData API
  • Technical service name: API_BUSINESS_PARTNER
  • Protocol: OData V2
  • Communication scenario (S/4HANA Cloud, public edition):
    Business Partner, Customer and Supplier Integration (SAP_COM_0008)

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/3c916ef10fc240c9afc594b346ffaf77/85043858ea0f9244e10000000a4450e5.html

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/3c916ef10fc240c9afc594b346ffaf77/f7399c7374d3475a96a56a0856b5f3ee.html

This API allows read, create, update, delete of Business Partner, Customer, and Supplier data

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/3c916ef10fc240c9afc594b346ffaf77/1e488b3c40ff4ed3a96be20d3850b26d.html

Extension custom fields:

Answer: Yes, custom BP fields can be read via this API, provided they are created and enabled correctly:

1. Create the custom field in business context
Master Data: Business Partner (BP_CUSTVEND1) using the Custom Fields app

 

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/0f69f8fb28ac4bf48d2b57b9637e81fa/339c235db4e6448ab01664008ee3036b.html

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/0f69f8fb28ac4bf48d2b57b9637e81fa/46632054fa9d49a18b452ee287173aba.html

2. On the UI tab enable usage for the Business Partner (A2X) service, then Publish.
The Business Partner (A2X) help explicitly states the API entities are extensible via Custom Fields

 

3. After publishing the custom field:

    • Appears in the OData service metadata.
    • Can be selected in $select and returned in read calls

So BP master data including extension fields is fully retrievable via API_BUSINESS_PARTNER as long as those fields are defined via Key User extensibility and enabled for the service.

Older IDoc-based options like DEBMAS/CREMAS exist but are explicitly not recommended for new integrations in current Public Cloud releases

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/3c916ef10fc240c9afc594b346ffaf77/a04825050c1740ef98032dccb2b8d682.html

Question 2.
Answer: Yes, but via the generic Journal Entry change SOAP API, not an AR-specific OData service.

On the FI open item journal entry line side, the payment block is stored as:

  • Field: PaymentBlockingReason the payment block key
  • It is available on the Operational Journal Entry Item / DebtorItem/CreditorItem structures

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/b978f98fc5884ff2aeb10c8fdeb8a43b/efabeff3bf8b4066ac03f0965d0a9327.html

Standard API that can change this:

  • API name (business): Journal Entry Change (Asynchronous)
  • Inbound service: JournalEntryBulkChangeRequest_In (SOAP)
  • Communication scenario: Finance Posting Integration (SAP_COM_0002)

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/6b39bd1d0e5e4099a5b65d835c29c696/5792333ddf3c47eaad4314b071dfd684.html

The Finance API documentation explicitly describes this service as the way to change journal entry data and notes that it can be extended with custom fields as well

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/b978f98fc5884ff2aeb10c8fdeb8a43b/c3833c31e7724a79b23e4273290f3e2e.html

The Operational Journal Entry Item help lists PaymentBlockingReason as a field in the structure used together with the Journal Entry APIs

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/b978f98fc5884ff2aeb10c8fdeb8a43b/efabeff3bf8b4066ac03f0965d0a9327.html

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/b978f98fc5884ff2aeb10c8fdeb8a43b/a524c714dcaf4bbc847c9aa584e10a40.html

Summary: Yes, you can toggle the payment block on AR open items via SOAP using Journal Entry Change (Asynchronous)

Question 3.
Answer: Yes

Standard OData API:

  • API name (business): Payment Advice (A2X)
  • Technical service name: API_PAYMENT_ADVICE_SRV
  • Protocol: OData V2
  • Communication scenario: Finance – Payment Advice Integration (SAP_COM_0331)

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/4f22209d1f5d4bd79c4a55017608b51b/b448d39b85dd4da6baf28e8c818f0e53.html

To register (create) a payment advice:

  • Send POST to
    /sap/opu/odata/sap/API_PAYMENT_ADVICE_SRV/A_PaymentAdvice
    with payload including PaymentAdviceType, CompanyCode, PaymentAdviceNumber, etc.

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/4f22209d1f5d4bd79c4a55017608b51b/5b8b271ca8004116bef1fe2c462076b0.html

The same service exposes entity sets for Payment Advice and Payment Advice Line Item and the Operations for Payment Advice documentation lists the standardCRUD operations

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/4f22209d1f5d4bd79c4a55017608b51b/6fc19bf0be0d4c3891e154f3e2b88eb6.html

There is also a SOAP API:

  • Payment Advice Create (PaymentAdviceNotification_In)
  • Also under the Finance Payment Advice Integration (SAP_COM_0331)

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/4f22209d1f5d4bd79c4a55017608b51b/dbc3550ceaa4431ebda046cba88086fb.html

In Public Cloud the documentation about Automatic Payment Advice Processing explicitly refers to both Payment Advice (A2X) and Payment Advice Create as the standard integration options

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/918bca53037f408f91a2295d04ac16bc/577f55d53e544fc0ae362aed52c5af39.html

Summary:

  1. BP master + extension fields:
    Yes, Business Partner (A2X) OData API API_BUSINESS_PARTNER with custom fields enabled via Custom Fields
  2. AR open item payment block toggle:
    Yes, via Journal Entry Change (Asynchronous) SOAP (JournalEntryBulkChangeRequest_In, scenario SAP_COM_0002). No AR-specific OData API, but line-item PaymentBlockingReason is supported there
  3. Payment advice registration:
    Yes, Payment Advice (A2X) OData API API_PAYMENT_ADVICE_SRV (scenario SAP_COM_0331) and optionally SOAP Payment Advice Create

Best Regards,

Dawid

entry.title: AI Boosted Asset Maintenance for Process Industries
entry.content:
Introduction & challenges in traditional asset management

Process industry & natural resources, or the Materials sector, are industries that manufacture chemicals, construction materials, forest products, glass, paper & packaging products, metals, minerals and mining commodities. In this sector products are produced by mostly continuous processing and process manufacturing but also a mix with discrete in the downstream value chain. These are highly asset intensive with complex production assets, plants, machinery, and equipment are running twenty-four hours a day, three hundred sixty-five days a year. Business success is strongly tied to productivity, asset availability and reliability of these assets because every shutdown or breakdown causes significant losses in production and margin.

These industries today face different types of pressures, both external and internal. Some of the driving external challenges include regulatory and compliance, sustainability requirements, talent and workforce shortage, as well as the acceleration in adoption of new technologies like AI. The internal struggles are linked to aging infrastructure, asset reliability, and necessity of saving costs.

Artificial Intelligence (AI) can play a big role in the transformation of these industries by optimising processes, predicting equipment failures, improving people efficiency with agentic approaches, as well as improving reliability of the assets with end-to-end integration.

Industry perspectives & some key aspects

Asset reliability and uptime are the most critical KPIs in process industries, where continuous operations depend on minimizing downtime and ensuring optimal performance of highly capital-intensive and complex assets throughout their lifecycle.

Uptime, or continuous operations, are essential for these industries. The assets usually run continuously (excluding annual or bi-annual planned shutdowns), and the overall business performance is highly dependent on Assets Reliability.

What are some of the key characteristics of process industries that make it unique?

  1. Companies in process industries are all highly asset & capital-intensive and normally have a wide variety of complex assets. Examples include fixed & continuous plants, like furnaces, crackers, reactors, distillation columns, mills, power generators, pumps and compressors as well as heavy equipment & mining machinery 
  2. Process Industry manufacturing runs as one production line, as one live organism, where breakdown or shutdown of even one equipment or unit stops the entire line and halts production. Bringing the whole production line to normal process conditions usually takes hours and even days, and during this time the business often spends many additional resources, raw materials and energy just to “start-up the line”
  3. The Mechanical Integrity of the Assets is key to ensuring that equipment and machinery are designed, installed, operated, and maintained in a way that supports their ongoing safety, reliability, and functionality throughout their lifecycle. These assets have high operational risk and work with dangerous substances (like acids, fuels) in high volumes. A top priority for all asset intensive companies is working to prevent    malfunctions & failures may cause danger to human life, significant damage to environment, and financial losses and penalties.
  4. In general, the life cycle of the production in process industries could last for years and demands very high investments and maintenance costs. To be sure the assets provide good return on investment, these assets are managed under the end-to-end business process “Acquire to Decommission”, which includes:
  • Acquisition: including design, procurement, engineering & construction or modernization during Overhauls, with subsequent handing over to maintenance & operations. There are high CAPEX costs involved in the entire lifecycle,
  • Maintenance Execution: starting from definition of maintenance strategy, asset condition monitoring, planning and execution of Maintenance. This stage also involves high OPEX costs and efforts for daily usage and maintenance,
  • Decommission: Including deconstruction of the assets at the end of life.

SAP portfolio and differentiators in Asset Maintenance:

The SAP portfolio for Asset Management delivers a comprehensive, integrated suite of solutions that optimize every aspect of asset lifecycle management: End to End Business Process “Acquire to Decommission”

This end-to-end process includes steps:

  • Manage asset master data
  • Define asset maintenance strategy
  • Define maintenance plans and activities
  • Monitor asset health and maintenance demand
  • Plan asset maintenance tasks and resources
  • Perform Asset Maintenance
  • Analyse asset and maintenance performance

  • SAP S/4HANA Plant Maintenance (PM) streamlines asset management, enabling efficient planning, execution of maintenance orders, and management of task lists to reduce downtime and extend asset life.
  • SAP Asset Performance Management helps organizations define asset strategies, analyse risks, connect to asset data and monitor asset conditions with predictive analytics, supporting proactive decision-making and reducing unexpected failures.
  • SAP for Resource Scheduling ensures optimal utilization of maintenance teams and resources, improving productivity and minimizing operational bottlenecks.
  • SAP Service & Asset Manager is a mobile app designed to support the work of service technicians and asset maintenance teams. It provides offline access to key information such as work orders, asset history, and spare parts inventory, enabling users to efficiently manage and execute service tasks even without network connectivity.
  • The SAP Partner Ecosystem Solutions further enrich this portfolio with specialized capabilities such as Asset Master Data governance, Shutdown Turnaround & Outage, Risk based inspections enabling tailored solutions for complex asset-intensive environments.
  • SAP Business AI to give more power. Business AI enhances asset maintenance processes across portfolio by automating tasks enhanced decision making, detecting anomalies, intelligent recommendations and agentic workflows. This also helps drives a shift by enhancing operational efficiency, enhancing decisions making also leading to reliability centric and prescriptive maintenance processes, leveraging data to anticipate equipment failures, automate workflows, and empower technicians.

Together, this extensive SAP solution portfolio provides customers in process industries with end-to-end visibility, improved reliability, and cost-effective asset management, driving operational excellence and sustainable growth.

The AI opportunity to transform Asset Maintenance practices for Process Industries

The Asset Management process supported by SAP have been quite mature and well-established for many years. While the traditional approach to manage assets has matured, new innovative technologies like AI are driving a huge transformation and are beginning to unlock new increases in key areas such as asset uptime and reliability.

Adding AI to asset management is a total game-changer for Process Industries. SAP Business AI really stands out by offering smart, predictive, and proactive ways to manage assets, making operations smoother and more efficient.

SAP Business AI uses machine learning and predictive analytics to shake up traditional asset management. In the SAP Portfolio we are delivering AI embedded scenarios in IAM Solution Portfolio: SAP Asset Performance Management (APM), 

Here’s AI-assisted capabilities by SAP which are already available for each area of asset management process flow:

 

Define asset maintenance strategy

  • Joule AI assistant helps to SAP Asset Performance Management (SAP APM) users with application help (link), application navigation and even in performing transactions using natural language (link)
  • ML for Failure Curve Analytics FCA which is part of SAP APM is capable to predict probabilities of failures for technical objects via calculation of Remaining Useful Life (link)
  • ML & Joule for Failure Mode and Effects Analysis FMEA assessments (link) is the scenario where ML helps to analyse and interpret system data such as past maintenance history and manufacturer recommendations to identify and propose unique failure patterns

Monitor asset health and maintenance demand

  • Machine Learning for Anomaly Detection – this ML capability provided by SAP APM allows the maintenance engineers and planner to effectively Identify and monitor unusual patterns or behaviour in technical objects (link) with lesser efforts
  • Next release of ML for Anomaly Detection capability also leverages ML to periodically re-evaluate and re-define the optimal threshold values (red, yellow, green zones) for alerting (link)
  • ML to monitor asset conditions from visual inspections is another SAP APM capability which collects images from cameras monitoring assets together with AI-derived indicator values, displays them in context of the asset history including other sensor data, and defines condition monitoring rules to create automated alerts and/or maintenance notifications (link)Plan asset maintenance tasks and resources
  • Maintenance Planner Agent which is capability of SAP S/4HANA helps maintenance planner to manage and prioritize a growing list of maintenance tasks with natural language conversation (link)
  • ML to Maintenance Order Recommendation helps user to create a new maintenance order in SAP S/4HANA via recommendation of historical one for copy – based on similarity of incidents (link)

Perform Asset Maintenance

  • Voice-to-text feature enables maintenance technicians to convert voice input into structured text, which is locally stored in Service and Asset Manager and later synchronized with the SAP Business Suite. By streamlining data capture, it helps technicians save significant time when recording job completion details while ensuring higher data quality, as no critical information is lost. It also enhances the mobile user experience by guiding users seamlessly through the job completion process (link)

Manage asset master data

  • SAP Partner Solution. Another example of AI for the Assets Maintenance is the improvement of EAM Master Data Management (Assets, Spare Parts, Measuring Point, Failure Modes, Task Lists, other objects) – ensuring the data quality, conversion of legacy master data from diverse data sources, checking for data white spaces and redundancies, and data enrichment with GenAI. This scenario and solution are supported by SAP Partner Ecosystem (link).  

Analyse asset and maintenance performance

  • SAP Business Data Cloud enables real-time, unified asset data for manufacturing, allowing asset managers to make faster, data-driven decisions and optimize maintenance strategies. By integrating SAP and third-party data (e.g. vendor provided asset health monitoring application), the platform breaks data silos and enhances predictive analytics with comprehensive business data semantic layer. This allows asset management experts both utilizing SAP provided intelligent dashboards and to build their own AI assisted applications to get business insights and forecasts.

Examples of SAP Business AI in IAM

Several top process manufacturing companies have started to successfully use SAP Business AI in their asset management. Here are a few examples:

Petrochemical Industry

A strong regional player in the petrochemical industry, has achieved a significant breakthrough in asset management by implementing SAP Data Platform with Data Storage and Machine Learning capabilities enabled. By leveraging these platforms, the company has established a robust system for asset health monitoring and predictive maintenance, specifically targeting pumps and compressors.

This approach involves continuously monitoring critical parameters such as vibration and temperature of key ball bearings and other vital components using IoT sensors and advanced analytics. Through the application of machine learning models, company can now identify potential failure patterns and predict equipment failures before they occur, triggering proactive maintenance actions in SAP ERP Plant Maintenance. This digital transformation minimizes unplanned downtime, optimizes maintenance schedules, and extends asset lifespans, ultimately leading enhanced operational reliability.

Renewables company 

A renewables company delivering 100% green power through multiple technologies (Biomass, Solar, Wind) across several geographies, resulting as a spin off from a Pulp and Paper company. After a round of investments, company felt the need to better manage their Power Generating Plants.

More than a Predictive Center, customer needed to replicate the operational data available in the plants and build a technical centre to support the operations and maintenance of all the plants. To achieve this, they have built solution based on SAP APM and SAP Datasphere infused with SAP AI capabilities not just to gather and store all the data to monitor complex assets health, but to predict and prevent malfunctions of the energy generation plant with all the electricity and steam generators.

Power Generation Industry

A large power generation company adopted SAP Predictive Insights to model digital twins to monitor and autogenerate alerts in case of abnormal behaviours. The company achieved exceptional results: 11% reduction of production losses, 35% productivity gains of maintenance, 100% reliability of generated alerts out of digital twin.

Construction Materials company

Company successfully implemented advanced condition monitoring and predictive maintenance using SAP Intelligent Asset Management and Asset Performance Management solutions, resulting in a significant reduction in unplanned downtime and millions in annual cost savings per plant.

The integration of IoT data with business systems, including the use of wireless sensors and AI-driven analytics, enables proactive identification of equipment failures, optimization of maintenance schedules, and minimization of unnecessary preventive tasks, improving overall operational efficiency. By implementing AI-powered predictive maintenance across multiple plants, the company has achieved $2 million in annual savings per plant by preventing unnecessary repairs.

Please follow this link to know more.

Benefits leveraging AI in asset maintenance for Process Manufacturing

SAP Business AI for Asset Maintenance provides additional value & benefits where traditional approach reached the limits, some of these are:

  • Helps increase reliability and prevents production losses

In process manufacturing, precision and efficiency are crucial. SAP Business AI provides insights into asset performance like predicting failures or recognizing abnormal patterns in health conditions data, which allows companies reduce downtime and to prevent excessive losses of production and revenue

  • Reduces Costs & Unplanned Downtime

Maintenance and operational costs can be a major headache for process manufacturers – especially when downtime and related maintenance were not planned. With a predictive maintenance approach, SAP Business AI helps cut down on how often assets fail and how severe those failures are, saving money on repairs and lost productivity

  • Optimizes both Maintenance Resources and Duration

Integrating AI into both the optimized planning and assistance in execution steps of the maintenance process enables the automation and optimization of tasks (as it was shown above), reducing workload and allowing users to focus on their primary responsibilities instead of spending time in the information system. Another effect of optimized planning and execution with AI is shortening the maintenance time thanks to assisted scheduling and execution.

What is next

Some of the capabilities SAP is planning for the next releases include the following: Improvements of AI-assisted Visual Inspections and Asset Condition Monitoring, Improved Anomaly Detection with Anomaly Scoring, Improvements of Joule Assistant to assist in user navigation and executing of system transactions like Risk and Criticality assessments, Management of Recommendations and Alerts, and others.

For more details please visit SAP Roadmap.

Getting SAP Business AI is more than just a tech upgrade; it’s a strategic investment for the future of process manufacturing. Embracing this will help companies handle the complexities of asset management with confidence and agility, setting them up for long-term success and growth.

Now for specific AI scenarios fitting the industry, and how to make them real - SAP supports & provides AI discovery services for customers with outcome being a list of customer specific scenarios, realization roadmaps and business outcomes.

Today business AI in asset maintenance for process industries is no longer a trend but a strategic imperative for achieving operational excellence & elevating the maintenance strategy management to the next level.

entry.title: Re: SAP Material Management Scope
entry.content:
Hi @saivarun_dubbaka ,
You are right, SAP Material Management (MM) is still a strong career option in 2025, especially in manufacturing, retail, and supply chain industries. For non-coding SAP modules, SAP FICO (Finance & Controlling), SAP SuccessFactors (HR), and SAP IBP (Integrated Business Planning) are among the most in-demand choices right now. SAP MM is a solid choice, but if you want broader career flexibility, SAP FICO and SuccessFactors are the safest non-coding bets in 2025.

Would you like me to create a comparison roadmap showing how long it typically takes to learn MM vs FICO vs SuccessFactors, and what entry-level salaries look like across regions? That could help you decide more clearly.

entry.title: Re: Part 2 – Empowering SAP BTP CAP Services through Open API Spec and Annotations for Effective Com
entry.content:
Hello @mohit_bansal3 
Nice blog!
What I found is adding Server.js is not mandatory, its way to register swagger plugins programmatically. By default cds-swagger-ui-express goes to devDependencies, if you move it to dependencies it will start swagger UI appraning without any code.

entry.title: Re: Goods Receipt(F0843) : Consider for Posting checked
entry.content:
Hello @SI_Sunaga 

Thank you for your question.

The simple answer is NO. I will explain below.

In summary, for subcontracting items, the system considers all compoents for posting by default. The extensibility option only exposes custom fields and a BAdI to change header and item data (for example movement type, quantities, etc). Here is a supporting document: https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/32da8359c8ee4e8b8e8c5e15cacba5aa/9ddf815494758c4ce10000000a4450e5.html?locale=en-US

It does not allow you to change the initial status of the "Consider for Posting" flag for each of the component. Which means, from a standard clean-core view point, the system will always preselect all subcontracting components when it opens the GR item.  Here is a supporting document: https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/32da8359c8ee4e8b8e8c5e15cacba5aa/df404e3e691f44eabd3fa2ee0412010d.html?locale=en-US

The fact that the component item is not managed by inventory explains why you get the error. The GR posting logic expects that all your components in the BOM which you have marked for posting to be handled by your Inventory Management, for example stock materials and possibly batches. If you include non inventory managed item as a component and you leave “Consider for Posting” checked, the posting will try to create something that you do not manage in stock and therefore leads to that error. So, basically the system works as designed.

Considering the public cloud does not offer a standard setting to uncheck Consider for Posting, I recommend:

  • You exclude such component from the subcontracting BOM and handle them separately, or
  • You keep them only for documentation and train your users to uncheck them, or
  • If you deem it appropriate, change your material type so that the component can be managed by inventory.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: How to link the demand of a planned order to a sales...
entry.content: When a sales order originates from a quotation, the system continues to reference the quotation number in the planned order. At present, there is no standard configuration to replace the quotation reference with only the sales order number. entry.title: Operating Concern and Controlling Area
entry.content:
1. One operating concern can contain multiple controlling areas.
  2. Operating Concern is the highest organizational unit in profitability analysis. (COPA) 
  3. Controlling Area is the highest organizational unit in Controlling (CO) 
  4. Controlling Area controls internal accounting, cost center accounting, internal orders, product costing, COPA settlement relations.
  5. Operating Concern defines how you want to analyze profitability (market-driven view).
  6. Operating Concern stores revenue, cost of sales, margins, contribution, characteristics, and value fields.
  7. Operating Concern can be mapped to multiple company codes condition all company codes must share same characteristics and values.
  8. Controlling Area can be mapped to multiple company codes condition all company codes must share same FYV and Chart of Account.
  9. Also can we say controlling area is for internal costing and operating concern is for profiability based on marketing and sales against external compnents like products, customers or zones ?

    Please let me know whether my understanding is correct. If not, I would appreciate guidance on any points I may have misinterpreted.

entry.title: Re: SAP IBP Configuration - Create a Copy Operator in SAP IBP
entry.content:
In SAP IBP, there is no standard transport mechanism to copy operator profiles from Sandbox → Production.

Operator Profiles belong to Configuration UI settings, and SAP does not include them in the Configuration Transport (CTS+) framework.

✅

Standard Options Available

 

There are only two supported approaches:

 

1️⃣ Manual Recreation (SAP-Recommended / Standard Way)

IBP expects Operator Profiles to be recreated manually in each system.

This is the official standard method.

Why?

Operator Profiles often contain system-specific elements like:

  • application jobs

  • calendars

  • data actions & filters

  • global parameters

  • user-specific variants

Hence SAP keeps them local.

2️⃣ Export/Import via Excel Template (Semi-Standard)

You can export operator profile settings using the Excel Operator Templates, then adapt and import them into Production.

This is the closest you get to a “copy” function, but still requires manual validation.

✔ Works for:

  • Time series operators

  • Copy operators

  • Planning operators

❗ Does not work for composite job templates or app-specific variants.

 

 

 

❌ What is NOT supported

 

 

  • No CTS transport

  • No migration cockpit

  • No automated script-based migration

  • No IBP add-in mass transfer for profiles

  • No API for operator profiles

 

 

 

 

3️⃣ For Large Landscapes – Practical Workaround

 

 

Some organizations maintain a central document library where all operator settings are described as templates, then recreate them consistently in each system.

 

 

 

Summary (one line)

There is no standard automated way to copy operator profiles in IBP; the standard method is manual recreation, optionally supported by Excel export/import.

entry.title: Accelerating Testing with SAP Cloud ALM and Tricentis TTA: Codeless Automation for RISE Transitions
entry.content:
In today's fast-paced agile environments, regression testing often becomes the bottleneck that slows down delivery cycles.

Teams face a challenging paradox: the need for comprehensive test coverage versus the pressure to release quickly.

Tricentis Test Automation for SAP integrated with SAP Cloud ALM offers a pragmatic solution that bridges this gap—one we've validated across multiple customer implementations in Latin America.

A Fool with a Tool Is Still a Fool

Before diving into the technology, let's address the elephant in the room.

The testing industry is littered with failed automation initiatives where organizations invested heavily in sophisticated tools only to see minimal return.

Why? Because they treated automation as a silver bullet rather than what it truly is: an enabler that amplifies your existing capabilities.

The best tool in the world won't compensate for poorly defined test strategies, unclear requirements, or teams that lack fundamental testing skills.

Tricentis TTA is powerful, but its success depends entirely on the people wielding it and the processes supporting them.

Codeless doesn't mean thoughtless.

The Agile Testing Challenge

Traditional regression testing approaches were designed for waterfall methodologies—lengthy test cycles executed at the end of development phases.

Agile demands something different: continuous validation that keeps pace with sprint cadences.

The question becomes not whether to automate, but how to automate intelligently within the constraints of time, budget, and team capacity.

Why Tricentis TTA for SAP Cloud ALM?

What makes this solution particularly attractive for agile teams is its core design philosophy: codeless, easy to use, and fast.

Being fully SaaS and hosted by SAP eliminates infrastructure overhead, allowing teams to focus on what matters—building quality into their releases.

The integration supports both SAP web and desktop applications, covering the majority of regression scenarios organizations face during S/4HANA implementations and ongoing operations.

For teams ready to begin, Tricentis provides clear guidance at https://docs.tricentis.com/sap-tta-calm-cloud/en-us/content/get_started.htm, with dedicated paths for administrators setting up the environment and testers building their first automated test suites.

Real-World Impact: Latin America RISE Transitions

Over the past months, we have successfully applied this solution across several customers in Latin America, and the results speak for themselves. Organizations undergoing RISE with SAP transitions, S/4HANA upgrades, and system conversions face an enormous regression testing burden—every customization, every integration, every business process needs validation.

Tricentis TTA integrated with SAP Cloud ALM has proven invaluable in these scenarios. The codeless approach allowed our customers' functional teams to participate directly in test automation, dramatically reducing the time needed to build comprehensive regression suites. What previously took weeks of manual testing effort could be automated and executed in hours, giving project teams the confidence to proceed with their transformations without compromising quality.

The SaaS delivery model was particularly beneficial for our Latin American customers, eliminating the need for complex on-premise infrastructure and enabling rapid deployment even in organizations with limited IT resources dedicated to testing.

Tools Succeed When People and Processes Align

In every successful implementation we've delivered, the common factor wasn't the tool itself—it was the combination of skilled testers who understood both the business and testing fundamentals, clear automation strategies defining what to automate and why, proper governance ensuring test assets remain maintainable, and executive sponsorship treating quality as a priority rather than an afterthought.

Tricentis TTA lowers the technical barrier to automation, but it doesn't eliminate the need for testing expertise. Use it wisely: automate the right things, maintain your test assets, and continuously evaluate whether your automation is delivering value.

Scaling Beyond SAP

For organizations looking to extend automation beyond SAP applications to their entire business landscape, the natural evolution path leads to SAP Enterprise Continuous Testing by Tricentis—providing a unified approach to quality across heterogeneous environments.

Practical Recommendations

Start with your most critical regression scenarios. Identify the business processes that run every sprint, carry the highest risk, and currently consume the most manual testing effort.

The codeless approach means your functional experts—those who understand the business—can contribute directly to automation without waiting for scripting resources.

For organizations planning RISE with SAP transitions or major upgrades, investing in TTA early in the project pays dividends throughout the journey—from initial testing through go-live and into steady-state operations.

But invest equally in your people. Train them, develop their skills, and ensure they understand not just how to use the tool, but when and why.

The path to agile quality assurance isn't about having the most sophisticated tools—it's about using the right tools effectively, with the right skills, within the right context.

SAP Cloud ALM

entry.title: Re: From On-Premise to Cloud: Making the Right SAP ERP Move
entry.content:
Hi Patrick,

Thanks for the feedback!

The Managed Service Provider (MSP) model is not described in this article because it is a unique delivery model that warrants a separate article. MSP is a partner company that contracts directly with SAP to purchase and resell SAP cloud solutions (such as SAP Cloud ERP Private) to its own end-customers - usually bundled with the MSP's own offerings.

The MSP manages the customer relationship independently. SAP’s contractual, operational, and support obligations exist only with the MSP, not with the MSP’s end-customers. 

The model comes with it's own guardrails and currently support SAP Cloud ERP Private, tailored option, but not all deployment- and delivery models as described in this article. Therefore, this should be assessed on a case-by-case basis through the SAP Technical Assessment process.

Hope that helps.

KR, Nikolaj
